text1:
Once the battlestation orbiting Opis, this station defended its host planet with an unbreakable veneer said to scare off all but the bravest(or most suicidal) enemies. When Opis was destroyed by the Planet-Killer device, the station itself escaped destruction, though it was heavily damaged. Trailing fusion fire and lacking many vital components, most, including the Sindrian Diktat at the time, left it to drift in the Opis Ring as yet another derelict structure.

Away from the prying eyes of the Diktat, a minor Independant polity formed within the dessicated hulk of the station, fending off prospective looters and subsisting on occasional supply shipments brought in by passing convoys. After a decade of such living, faced with the detiororation of what was left of the station's life support systems and the rapid worsening of living conditions aboard, the polity signed an agreement with the Sindrian Diktat; in return for refurbishing the station into workable condition, the polity would join the Sindrian Diktat.

Nowadays, the rechristened Opis Mining Platform acts as the central collection hub and processing facility for mining operations spanning the mineral rich Opis RIng. Retaining its combat modules from the days of the Askonia Crisis, it acts as a safe port for those who wish to earn a fortune mining rich ore belts or tech-mining the remains of Opis, yet are not quite as desperate as the workers at Cruor. Since it's restoration, millions of refugees from Volturn have been moved to the slightly more comfortable hab-rings of the Opis Mining Platform, swelling its population and providing the industries there with plenty of fodder to put to work.
text3:
Many critics, both within and outside the Diktat have criticised the continued existence of the Opis Mining Platform, as well as questioned the payout for the otherwise considerable effort needed to restore a station of such scale to the state it currently operates at. Of course, the Diktat would never make such an investment for such trivialities as sentimentality; as your shuttle lands on the docking strip and you dis-embark, the massive sheets of metal being prepared for export around you make clear the Diktat's purpose for restoring such a structure.

Not only being the main orbital defense of Opis, Opis Station also contained an extensive refinery on a scale not possible anywhere else in Askonia. While much of the refinery was heavily damaged during the Askonia Crisis and was hence rendered inoperable, DIktat efforts to restore this facility have proven successful and now, the Opis Mining Platform is a major exporter of metals and transplutonics, raking in a considerable profit this way as well as further alleviating Diktat reliance on exports.

text1:
A comparatively new station compared to other structures like the Opis Mining Platform, this station was intended to be the crux of Sindrian Diktat autarky policies, to rid them of a persistent volatiles crutch that existed since Umbra broke off from the Diktat. Whisking volatiles from the magnetosphere of Salus, the station provides the Diktat with a modest supply of volatiles, which is nontheless essential to the Diktat's efforts.

Unlike the older stations of Sindria and the Opis Mining Platform which follow after their original builders, the Domain, in low-tech design, or like Volturn Station which took after the midline school of thought, the Salus Siphon Platform uses techniques and styles from the high-tech school of design. This has lead to controversy about how the Diktat built the station, with the most popular theory being that the Diktat hired the Tri-Tachyon to build, or haul, a station there. Such baseless rumours are vehemently denied by Diktat officials.
text3:
Unlike the crowded bustle of other Diktat territories like Volturn or Sindria, the Salus Siphon Platform is sparsely populated in comparison. Only a population in the mere tens of thousands live here, mostly professionals who have the expertise necessary to operate the delicate siphon equipment. As the station itself was not built to accomodate large masses of people, refugees were not allowed aboard it, with only a few with the aforementioned skills being allowed to reside there.

The docking zone is fairly empty, likely due to this reason; Only a few ships have landed here, mostly traders looking to ship volatiles somewhere else or Diktat convoys performing in-system routes to Sindria. Of course, it isn't a Sindrian Diktat territory without the propaganda; Everywhere you look, posters and holograms proudly showing the Lion's face to everyone in sight can be seen.

text1:
Named for the dragon-like megafauna that once dominated the planet, Drakon is a mercilessly cold world rivaling even Umbra in frigidity. Much of the organics harvesting and processing plants lie underground, with almost no sign of human habitation on the surface. Not many would come here willingly, feeding rumours that the Diktat sends their prisoners here to work their usefulness away deep under the frozen crust.

According to archaelogical finds, Drakon was once a lush paradise in the heart of the Askonia system, enjoying the warmth of its parent star when it was still middle-aged. However, a few hundred million years ago, Drakon suffered a catastrophic collision with another planetary body, causing the extinction of much of the local fauna and sending the planet into a slow spiral outwards from the Askonia system. Eventually, anything that survived the initial impact died to the lowering temperatures, as Drakon slowly but surely froze over. Not even the aging of Askonia into a red giant could heat up the now long-frozen planet. By the time the Domain arrived, it was nothing different from hundreds of other barren rocks in the Sector.

What remains of life on this planet was buried deep under its crust; massive oceans of organics dwell underneath Drakon, occasionally erupting onto the surface in black gouts that soon freeze, forming bands of greyish black along the planet's surface. However, these massive reservoirs of organics went untouched until recently, as nobody would willingly immigrate to such an inhospitable world without payment, and most decided that the costs of hazard pay overruled any possible profits made. This changed when the Diktat arrived; supposedly, they did so as they could waive the costs of hazard pay by bringing in prisoners from Cruor; helping them secure the profitable organics reserves for minimal costs. Of course, these are all frivolous rumours propagated by anti-Diktat elements; surely no faction would be so heartless as to force prisoners onto this hellhole of a planet.
text3: From orbit, the planet seems almost dead; only the flickers of lights surrounding surface-bound maintainence and emergency shafts serve as evidence that humans even live on it. The entire planet is only serviced by a single, small port; and this port itself is nothing more than a large hole drilled into the ground protected by a massive set of blast doors. Evidently, the Diktat did not intend for this planet to see heavy traffic; the only other ships that come here are those of mercantile convoys ferrying organics to other markets.

text1:
The barren moon of Drakon, this body is theorized to have formed out of the debris surrounding Drakon after the collision that pushed it out to the fringe of the Askonia system. Despite this, the moon did not have much characteristics or resources of interest for the Diktat, hence never being colonized.

Despite the apparent disinterest towards this moon by any major power, tales of weak EM signatures and faint lights being observed from this planet have sowed the seeds for conspiracy theories claiming that Parthevia is home to a series of underground secret Diktat military bases testing novel and experimental technologies. Such rumours are generally brushed off as the ravings of madmen by more sound-minded spacers.

The heavily armed and shielded bastion over Sindria, this massive station takes solemn guard over its host planet, and hosts much of the administrative structures for governance of the planet below, whenever deemed too valuable to risk being put with the commoners and possible terrorist attacks. Some say it keeps an eternal, watchful eye on Sindria, waiting for any sign of dissidence to pop up, and disappear them into the pages of history. To that point, it's often depicted in Sindrian folk stories as a thousand-eyed deity, watching for anyone who steals, cheats or sleeps too late at night to drag them to Hell.
text3: Upon closer inspection, it becomes obvious that the station once had a large coat of Lion's Guard paint; however, intense solar winds from Askonia have long since stripped most of it off, leaving nothing but dirty streaks of the once grand crests dotting the station. Closing in to the gigantic station, it's obvious every part of it is also heavily armoured head to toe; as well as signs of what you identify as a station-wide variant of Solar Shielding. Docking inside a large hangar bay guarded by an intimidatingly large set of blast doors with the Diktat crest painted over them, you depart your shuttle and move into the depths of the surprisingly crowded station.

text1: Once a luxury habitat containing the system's finest casinos and residences to please the wealthy, the Juturnus Control Garrison's role hasn't actually deviated too far since then; the station serves as the residence of anyone priveliged enough to not be forced to live on Volturn's actual surface. With its vast casino hallways converted into military barracks, it now serves as the local headquarters for the garrison that keeps a shaky rule over the riotous planet below.
text3: The station still sports glamorous arches and pillars all along its berth, tasteful remnants of its former role; while much of this has been preserved, the lower arches have noticeably been crudely cut open to sport large ship hangars for the garrison's patrols. Midline combat modules, hastily welded onto the upper sections of the station, lazily track your fleet's arrival with their weapon arcs.

text1: The Phrygian Immigration Checkpoint is a small station put into orbit over the Salus L4 Jump Point by the Diktat to perform security checks, willing or unwilling, on any fleet that attempts to enter the system by this jump point. Crewed by a relatively small population due to the boredom of this job; most scans are autonomously conducted by Delta-level AIs and most personnel are solely there as punishment, because they fail to qualify for anything better or for some other reasons.
text3: As you close to the station, your fleets report an intrusive fleetwide scan originating from it; evidently Phrygian will do its job regardless of consent. The admin you contact on it just tells you to "not worry about it".

text1:
Primarily composed of hydrogen and helium gases. The temperature and pressure at the core are extreme, but not enough to sustain the deuterium fusion that would turn the planet into a brown dwarf star.

Before the Collapse, Bardonia was renowned for its posse of moons, meticulously terraformed into lush paradises that each provided a unique and memorable view. From thick tropical jungles to vast grassy plains, towering redwood forests to shifting desert sands, each moon offered an experience nothing like the one before. Known as the number one tourist attraction in the local galactic venue and a must-go for any vacationeer this side of the galaxy, the moons enjoyed a wealth of income from their lucrative tourism industries.

However, everything changed when the Collapse occurred. Suddenly cut off from their main(and in many cases only) form of income, society on many moons quickly decivilized. The few remaining civilized moons survived on crude and previously useless secondary industries, banding together to form the Andor Polity. Despite this, the moons retained their lush biospheres and such jewels were too valuable to simply ignore for the major powers of the Sector. Many of these moons were colonized by the Hegemony, League, Tri-Tachyon and even some taken by privateers and independants. There existed a tenuous peace between them for decades.

Though, if one looks on now, the moons of Bardonia look nothing like the tourist worlds they once were. Many are now barren balls of rock, retaining no trace of life or anything economicaly useful at all. Nobody quite knows what happened to them; any residual information that was not deleted with the Hypernet was thoroughly censored by Tri-Tachyon for reasons unknown. The only known information about this event is that it is called the Razing of Bardonia's Moons among spacers, and that it resulted in almost all of Bardonia's moons becoming barren wastelands. Of course, there are always rumors, conspiracies and theories but most are so far-fetched they could only be the work of a rad-addled mind that's spent far too much time under a Gremlin's phase coil.

Once one of Bardonia's "tourist moons", this moon is barren and dead now for reasons unknown. A thin, reduced atmosphere stubbornly clings on to the moon, a remnant of its once habitable atmosphere. A cursory scan brings up meagre deposits of ores and rare ores, but considering the danger of settling a colony here and their miniscule quantity, it would be unwise to colonize this moon.

The newest of Bardonia's "tourist moons", Ravaryea was in the midst of being terraformed when the Collapse occurred. It was relatively unaffected by the chaos of the Collapse as no humans lived on the moon at that time, and the terraforming drones slowly turned it from the barely-habitable rock it was on the eve of the Collapse into a lush jungle world. The League was in the midst of preparing a colonization convoy to it when Ravaryea, like all of Bardonia's moons were suddenly reduced back into barren rocks. In a twist of fate, whatever had consumed Ravaryea's biosphere did not, or could not, severely damage the terraforming drones that had created that biosphere, and they resumed their mindless work, re-terraforming Ravaryea. Now, due to their work, it is the only habitable moon in Bardonia's orbit, even if "habitable" may be a minor overstatement.

The razing of Bardonia's moons permanently cut any major faction's interest in the system; it's only strategic value depleted, most factions made no move to recolonize Andor. Hence, the Diktat managed to pluck Ravaryea out from under the other power's noses; it is now a bastion of authority in the Andor system, or whatever authority is left anyway.
text3: Ironically, Ravaryea has followed in the footsteps of the other moons of Bardonia, earning much of its profit from tourism related activities, while still maintaining a decent secondary profit from farming and mining activities exploiting its modest reserves of organics. With the more terraformed parts of Ravaryea boasting bountiful jungles rivaling those of Jangala while not having a human-deadly biosphere, or without the cumbersome anti-technology restrictions placed on tourists on Gilead, there is understandably a high demand to spend a vacation on what is one of the more beautiful planets in the Sector with few of the disadvantages to boot. To this end, Ravaryea contains the highest percentage of tourist attractions in the Sector; definitely a must-go for any prospective traveler with enough credits in their pockets. Even the Diktat has been quick to play themselves into this advantage, making the planet as accomodating as possible for tourists from any faction.

text1:
Once one of Bardonia's "tourist moons", this moon is barren and dead now for reasons unknown. A thin, reduced atmosphere stubbornly clings on to the moon, a remnant of its once habitable atmosphere. A cursory scan brings up meagre deposits of ores and rare ores, but considering the danger of settling a colony here and their miniscule quantity, it would be unwise to colonize this moon.

Despite this, privateers have set up a small settlement here, mostly for the purposes of raiding Ravaryea. Small, crude hab-domes lie scattered across the moon's rocky surface,  blinking lights pock-marking the ceaseless gray surface. While originally intending to raid Ravaryea for profit, the pirates here more often find themselves raiding for food and supplies just to keep their settlement going, as any and all incoming shipments are scrutinized thoroughly by Diktat patrols. This has made the colony rather unpopular among pirates, and only the foolish or desperate would come here willingly.

What formerly appeared to be a massive Venus-like planet with a thick atmosphere, much of Farnau's atmosphere was blown away when Andor transitioned into a blue supergiant. While what remains contains a high concentration of useful minerals, Farnau's close proximity to its star and the resultant consequences on it outweighs any possible benefits of exploiting these rich bands of ores.

Once one of Bardonia's "tourist moons", this moon is barren and dead now for reasons unknown. A thin, reduced atmosphere stubbornly clings on to the moon, a remnant of its once habitable atmosphere. Unlike the other moons, Savras' surface does not yield even the smallest deposits of useful minerals; almost as if it had been picked clean by an unknown force.
text3: Once the "capital" of the Bardonian Moons Tourism Association, it was the place where travellers would initially stop at before embarking on sub-burn transport shuttles to the other moons. Now it lies dead much like the other moons of Bardonia. Surprisingly enough, your scans indicate that there are a few weak EM waves being emitted from various points on the planet's surface. Their distance from the ruins of starports and the non-civilian wavelength implies that they were likely military in origin, while the relatively strong signals imply they were far more recently built than the civilian structures. Further scans indicate that most of the sites were ravaged by the Razing of Bardonia's moons; almost nothing remains, and anything that could have been salvageable was looted long ago.

text1: Formerly a luxurious orbital made to present wealthy tourists with a picturesque view of the system's asteroid belt and main star, this structure was abandoned soon after the Collapse as its lack of self-sufficiency drove the workers and remaining tourists there to depart in the hopes of finding a better world or station to call home. Now, the refurbished structure acts as a training ground for prospective Lion's Guard officers, in preparation for active duty in Askonia. Due to this, the facility sports a modern military base, whose fleets protect both the Viewport and nearby Ravaryea.
text3: The cavernous spaces of the luxury villa-modules have been converted into classrooms, training zones and dorm-modules for up-and-coming Guard officers, with the hallways packed with these promising candidates. The station, surprisingly, sports a crude Heavy Industry base, which is populated by students of the Guard Academy here on part-time jobs. Working in the Heavy Industry here is considered an honourable way to serve the Lion of Sindria, and hence the assembly lines never experience a shortage of willing workers.

text1: Once used to provide the highest quality FPS to tourists watching holovids on their TriPads from hotel rooms on the Moons of Bardonia, this relay now transmits and receives data between star systems at impressive faster-than-light speeds, even among other Domain-era comm relays. The rapidly pulsing hyperwaves suitable for FTL data transmission have been shown to damage DNA so these relays are always stationed away from habitats.

Like Ismara, Lennox was the perfect location to install mines and mass-driver facilities to launch mega-tonne slabs of graphene-encased water and nitrogen packages toward the inner system to nurture the moons of Bardonia. Cycles before the Collapse, much of Lennox's infrastructure was already repurposed for other terraforming projects out-sector, leaving a skeleton crew to occasionally supplement the terraformers on Ravaryea with incoming comets of ice. When the Collapse occurred, this population of mere hundreds was able to leave the planet for better prospects, leaving Lennox as cold and dead as when the Domain first found it.
text3: Much of Lennox's infrastructure had been stripped pre-Collapse; what was left has been looted long ago. Now, there is nothing but the bare foundation of hab-domes and mass driver tracks to see, and certainly nothing of use to salvage.

text1: This once-modest siphon platform has been buried under dozens of hab-modules and armour segments ripped out from other stations over the course of a decade. While originally meant only to siphon volatiles from Ryzan, with support of various scavenged bastions and armour segments, it now forms a logistical hub for Diktat operations in the Andor system, as well as a fall-back capital for if Sindria is ever taken from the Diktat.
text3:
The station's previous administration was destroyed in a destructive civil war not long after the Collapse, leaving the station uninhabited for decades. The destruction wrought by the war left the station too broken to be deemed recoverable, and looters slowly took away portions of its superstructure before the Razing of Bardonia's Moons. After which, the station was never touched again until early 190, when the Diktat colonized it looking to exploit Ryzan's volatiles, as well as making it a potential logistics hub on a scale unachievable on Ravaryea or the Andoran Viewport, and unecenomical on any other Andoran body.

To this point, the Diktat went on a decade-long rampage; destroying Pather and Pirate bases where they stood, to bring their hab-modules and armour plates back to reinforce the Ryzan Supercomplex. A decade later, this paid off; the station is now covered with haphazardly bolted hab modules and coated in thick sheets of armour that could make an Onslaught look like a Kite in comparison. The combat modules were enhanced too; with the copius amount of battlestation-class modules and armour segments recovered from Pather bases, Ryzan Supercomplex now operates a star fortress matched only by Command and Control.

text1: This small frozen colony of Tri-Tachyon was never of any great significance to the Corporation, and hence avoided annexation by the Hegemony for the same reasons. A lonely world, duty here is often considered a punishment for dissident or lazy employees, in the hope that the desolate environment would teach them to behave better in the workplace.

A former Tri-Tachyon staging point for the Invasion of Chicomoztoc, Itztlacoliuhqui's near proximity to the Hegemony's capital garunteed its annexation by the Hegemony. However, mere days before the handover, Itztlacoliuhqui's administration underwent a catastrophic collapse and the planet decivilized, with the remaining populace destroying anything that could still be looted from the military base there. The Hegemony blamed Tri-Tachyon for causing the collapse, while Tri-Tachyon denied involvement in what it said was an isolated incident. In any case, with the military base looted and with no other resources on the planet being of sufficient interest to justify recolonization, the planet was left empty.
text3: Orbiting over the planet, your sensors detect EM readings from low-grade handheld weaponry and guided rockets; looking to where the military base once stood, what is left has been shattered, blasted and thoroughly vandalized.

text1: Once a major Tri-Tachyon military base second only to Culann, its proximity to the Persean League and its established military facilities made it a tempting target for the Hegemony. However, a few days before the expected handover, the planet's administration unexpectedly declared independence from Tri-Tachyon. While the Hegemony could still invade and take the planet by force, attacking an otherwise innocent independant polity would not sit well among the public, hence the colony was left as it is. Now, Kukayin is a large independent military base renowned more for its prodigious sales of drugs than its military prowess, being a consistent pain in the rear for the other colonies of Zagan by encouraging the proliferation of in-system smuggling.
text3: The independent polity governing the planet surprisingly retained many features of its Corporation parent; a corporational structure, liberal laws on commodities and lower tax rates. However, one notable difference is that the polity treats its workers notably better than the Corporation usually does. Drug usage is a common practice here, less out of neccessity and more out of a deep-seated culture prevalent amongst the former Tri-Tachyon employees that once worked here, and still is popular amongst the citizens here.

text1: This frozen ball was, believe it or not, once a lush water world orbiting in a curiously binary orbit with similarly-sized Bheur. While many interesting phenomenon have been implicated to occur between the two, Hybrasil's collapse into a white dwarf froze the two planets, locking their oceans under metres-thick ice drifts. Despite this, large pockets of ocean thousands of kilometres wide still exist deep under Cailleach, which are now being exploited for their agricultural benefits.
text3: Pre-Collapse, the planet's only inhabitation was a small research base dedicated to investigating the planet's binary orbit with Bheur, as well as its semi-frozen ocean, helmed by Tri-Tachyon. Post-Collapse, the research base was quickly refurbished into a full on settlement, the subterranean seas dredged with fish farms and kelp plantations which help Cailleach export a sizable quantity of food.

text1: The binary sister to Cailleach, Bheur still retains subterranean seas like its sister planet, but unlike Cailleach, Bheur's seas are laden with large quantities of soluble toxic minerals that prevent them from being used agriculturally. This, alongside a few other factors made it a less desirable locale to colonize compared to Cailleach, and hence no settlement was founded here.

Once a moderately-sized Tri-Tachyon military base, Aisoyimstan was handed to the Persean League by Tri-Tachyon in the face of its imminent defeat in the Second AI War, preventing it from being seized by the Hegemony in the Treaty of Crom Croach. While this angered the Hegemony, they ultimately did not do anything to stop the transfer and this colony now acts as a strong bastion in the depths of League space.

Once a bustling independent freeport serving as a bastion of legal and illegal trade bound for the inner Andoran markets utilizing Erreichen's rings as a source of mineral export and smuggling cover, this station was destroyed by a violent Diktat crackdown on its activities in 192; intended not only to stop the station's influence on smuggling into Diktat territories, but also to display to the other factions the Diktat's military might. The bloody conflict involved dozens of ships lost, thousands of dead on both sides and ultimately resulted in the gutting of the station by an intentional reactor self-destruct in a final act of retribution towards the Diktat by the ruling polity. Its cold, dead wreck now slowly orbits Erreichen in a pool of its own detritus, a grim reminder of the Diktat's military strength.

While the act of hostility towards an otherwise neutral entity was met with widespread condemnation throughout the Sector, no major faction took decisive action. The operation was a success not only in neutralizing the port's influence on unlawful operations in Askonia, but also of convincing the major powers in the Sector of the Diktat's military prowess, and no faction was willing to undertake what was likely to be a long and bloody conflict to remove the Diktat from power.

Erreichen is what Old Earth astrologists would call a "Super Saturn"; dominating Andor's outer system, this massive ice giant has coalesced most of the primordial matter left from Andor's birth into massive, awe-inspiring rings dwarfing those of Saturn. Visible even to the naked eye even from the inner system, this foreboding giant is a magnificent sight to behold, and it's dense rings provide the perfect cover for smugglers negotiating illegal trade of goods on the Andoran fringe.
text3: Even from here you can see the distant flicker of lights and faint EM readings that signal small roider fleets in Erreichen's rings. Many spacefarers make their livings off mining asteroids in the rings, and more often than not, live and die amongst them too; asteroid habitats are not an uncommon sight here, and the chaotic nature of the ring means one moment of distraction and one's ship could be smashed into twisted scrap by a hurtling asteroid.

text1: Duden is a relatively new planet in astronomical timescales; only having been birthed a mere million or so years ago from the coalescing of asteroids in Erreichen's rings. While this birth has gifted it with higher-than-average mineral composition, its high hazard rating would dissuade all but the most desperate entrepreneurs from setting up a mining outpost here.

This station was used to coordinate the waves of drone miners that seasonally mined Nortia pre-Collapse, acting as a hub for mining operations. After the Collapse,  the station remained operational, but was eventually sabotaged by Pathers in cycle 83 due to allegations of AI core usage on the station. The act left the station crippled and incapable of further operation, which led the independent polity controlling Nortia at the time to leave it abandoned. Ever since then, the station has not been restored by any succeeding government, leaving it to slowly drift over Nortia.

This small planetoid was formed out of collisions of asteroids in Bardonia's L5 Lagrange Point, and over the millenia has converted many of the asteroids in the L5 into impressive rings. Only the larger asteroids remain, unfortunately enough to semi-regularly bombard Fornois at a rate considered to be hazardous for any above-ground structures.

A large planet orbiting in the Largrange Point between Valhalla and Ragnar, Midgard sits inside the habitable zone of both stars and gets enough light from both to sustain photosynthesis and hence was considered a desirable terraforming candidate. Like Gilead, it was terraformed by the Eridani-Utopia Corporation to serve as a biological repository of flora and fauna species salvaged from Old Earth during its devastation by human-wrought climate change. After the Collapse, the administration on the planet sought independence from the ailing Domain, converting the planet's fertile soil into farmland and bolstering its population by assisting other colonies, eventually reaching a size and development rivaled only by Mairaath of the Mayasuran Terraforming Cabal. However, unlike Mairaath, Midgard has survived independence through the tumultous cycles since, serving as a shining star for the other independent colonies that there is yet hope for them.
text3:
Midgard's garrison, once only meant to deter piracy attempts and small rebellions, has expanded into a massive navy rivaling that of the greatest superpowers of the Sector, having stopped numerous incursions on Midgard, including one from the Hegemony. With their reputation so high, many people from all walks of life and allegiances come here to disappear from the eyes of the greater sector, protected from their aggressors by the massive fleets surrounding Midgard.

Not only do people come for safety, they also come for the sights and smells. As Midgard was one of the Domain's "biological treasuries", its biodiversity allows a large range of fauna and flora unheard of anywhere else. It makes for a remarkably diverse culture of cuisine using various exotic ingredients, as well as extremely profitable tourist attractions and great zoo material.

text1: The Valhalla-Ragnar Logistical Hub was, as its name states, a logistical centre for the Valhalla-Ragnar system, coordinating all other efforts in-system from the Asgard Orbital Complexes to the Volatiles mining operations on Skathi, as well as the planet below it. It also served a secondary purpose as a luxurious orbital for the administrators of Midgard to recline in, and a tourist destination for those interested in viewing Midgard's wondrous biodiversity from above. Post-Collapse, the Hub was rapidly converted into a military and residential complex, ring after ring of hab-modules and combat segments burying the original structure. Now it serves as the home of many hundreds of thousands, as well as the primary defense of Midgard beyond its fleets.
text3: Living on Midgard itself is often a luxury; much of the poorer citizens of Midgard stay here instead, where housing prices are cheaper. Population on the station is higher than on Midgard itself, with a thriving food culture weaving its way up from the planet below into the station; the wet markets here sell a variety of street food not seen anywhere else, made with ingredients found only on Midgard.

text1:
The Asgard Orbital Complexes were heavy orbital stations built in Midgard's L4 and L5 Lagrange points by the Domain during the terraforming of Midgard. Imposing in their bulk, they served as military training bases and projection venues for the Domain across the local sectoral venue, as well as protection for Midgard and as the site of orbital work factories for the production of military components, fuel production facilities and refineries. After the Collapse, the administrations of these complexes had to scuttle or sell off much of the Domain-era components in the complexes to stay afloat, relying on supplies and food from Midgard to continue operating.

In cycle circa-85 post-Collapse, emboldened by the victories at Mairaath, the Hegemony launched an attack against Midgard and the two Asgard Orbital Complexes. The L4 Asgard Orbital Complex was seized by Hegemony forces, dealing a huge blow to the Midgardian polity. However, the Hegemony forces were eventually forced into a stalled battle over Midgard, causing massive losses and eventually prompting the High Hegemon to withdraw from Midgard amidst free-falling public opinion about the war. To this day, the L4 Asgard Orbital Complex serves as a Hegemony refueling post, refinery and military garrison, keeping an eye on Midgard.

The Asgard Orbital Complexes were heavy orbital stations built in Midgard's L4 and L5 Lagrange points by the Domain during the terraforming of Midgard. Imposing in their bulk, they served as military training bases and projection venues for the Domain across the local sectoral venue, as well as protection for Midgard and as the site of orbital work factories for the production of military components, fuel production facilities and refineries. After the Collapse, the administrations of these complexes had to scuttle or sell off much of the Domain-era components in the complexes to stay afloat, relying on supplies and food from Midgard to continue operating.

In cycle circa-85 post-Collapse, emboldened by the victories at Mairaath, the Hegemony launched an attack against Midgard and the two Asgard Orbital Complexes. The L5 Asgard Orbital Complex was fatally crippled during the fierce fighting between Hegemony and Midgard forces, and while the Hegemony emerged victorious, the station was deemed unrestorable. It was looted and then scuttled by Hegemony forces, with what left being picked clean by scavengers over the decades.

The beginning of the end for most stars, the white dwarf was once a red giant not massive enough to fuse carbon. Extremely dense and slowly radiating away its heat as it no longer undergoes fusion reactions, its volume is supported against gravitational collapse only by electron degeneracy pressure.

However, Hesiod is noted for being an extremely young white dwarf on the stellar scale, having only begun the conversion from a red giant relatively recently on the stellar timescale. It is so young in fact that it still sheds what remains of its outer layers even now, finalizing the transformation into a white dwarf. This characteristic has left the immediate space around Hesiod saturated in isotopes and gases that find critical usage in AM fuel production applications.

The Brontes Bay Module was one of three hub modules that once made up the Apollodorus Harvesting Complex that rung all around Hesiod, now one of the only surviving remnants of the structure. The Brontes was built to accommodate large amounts of bulk cargo ships arriving to pick up raw volatiles and minerals from the Complex, and hence was the only module to sport large bays fit for even the largest of haulers.
text3: While the structure is certainly looted thoroughly, the cavernous space the bays in the module provide can be used to store a vast quantity of ships and commodities alike. The only truly notable feature are the large amount of spray-painted Luddic-analogous symbols on the walls of the bays.

text1: The Steropes Power Module was one of three hub modules that once made up the Apollodorus Harvesting Complex that rung all around Hesiod, now one of the only surviving remnants of the structure. The Steropes was built to manufacture and run on limited amounts of AM fuel to sustain the rest of the Complex, sporting cavernous open-space segments for ease of AM fuel synthesis and a large amount of generators to run on said fuel. The production capacity was never enough for export purposes.
text3: Even from a distance, holes of varying size can be seen pock-marking the structure, from as small as a regular crew member to as large as a capital ship. These seem remniscent of detonations caused by destabilized AM fuel and have rendered much of the structure damaged. Most of the generators have also conspicuously been looted, or destroyed, sometimes with the mangled wrecks of starships too wrecked to warrant salvage. Unfortunately, the fleet is reduced to sightseeing as this module has no docking ports avaliable for ships, while the structure evidently seems to be looted to the bone.

The Arges was built to act as a giant collector for the vast amounts of volatiles that still spew out of Hesoid, using a Plasma Dynamo(with relevant modifications) to catch as many volatiles as possible around the fading star.
text3: The broken tendrils of giant fan-like collectors can be seen protruding from the lower half of the module, stretching to various heights. The famed Plasma Dynamo itself is still there; however sensory scans indicate that extended exposure to Hesiod's solar flares and radiation, as well as age have rendered it practically inoperable and hence useless...as well as a few massive munitions blasts in its side. Unfortunately, the fleet is reduced to sightseeing as this module has no docking ports avaliable for ships, while the structure evidently seems to be looted to the bone.

text1: A large and imposing gas giant, the only planet to survive Hesiod's transformation from a red giant to a white dwarf. The planet regularly captures gases from the surrounding space giving it the same plentiful isotopes as the nebular remnant it is situated deep in. The solar winds from Hesiod also indirectly contribute to massive storm cells and generally violent weather that rages across the planet.
text3: Even from space the raging storms of Cronus can be seen; storms the size of terrestrial planets rage, urged on by winds that would blow away any atmospheric settlement that would be established on the planet. A peculiar sight is what seems to be a ring of small black dots along the equator of Cronus; likely the impact points of a ring of gas siphon platforms that apparently used to exist around Cronus according to Tri-Pad data, that were pushed into the planet by their own wear and tear and the force of solar wind against their failing boosters.

A few clumsily spray painted slogans, suspiciously similar to a somewhar tilted Luddic Church symbol seem to hint at to who the culprit may have been responsible. And the Plasma Dynamo? A mangled wreck, seeming to have been shot at multiple times by some ship-bound weapons in its slot.

text1: Surprisingly enough, the Tri-Pad brings up nothing on this peculiar planet; not even the stereotypical description used for planets of its class. Unusual, as the planet seems mostly non-anomalous from a far view. Perhaps a closer look might be warranted.

Although, some of the craters look fresher than others. One notable crater is a massive one directly underneath the mysterious station orbiting it; magma still flows between the cracks, implying it was made recently.

text1: This small station seems to be hidden in low earth orbit over the planet; its orbit tailored specifically to keep as close to the planet as possible to avoid detection. The Flurry is a bomber designed to soften up enemy shields before a strike by other ships. While its payload is intimidating, the bomber's slowness and relative fragility undermine its effectiveness on the battlefield.

Due to lax regulations, undercut funding, and general apathy from Andrada, the Sindrian Diktat's few original fighter projects often mix zany ideas with incompatible hullmods, ending up with fighters that act more like proof of concepts than actually useful designs. The few that get the Lion's attention and manage to reach mass production in Diktat circles often don't perform quite as well as existing mass production fighters.

The Flurry was the brainchild of a minor fleet admiral whose only distinctive features was his downright cult-like obsession over Squalls, claiming that they were the "one true missiles" and that "sabots can eat my burn". To that point, he attempted to make an entire bomber focused solely around the Squall, which understandably did not go down well with most fighter development branches. Only in the Diktat's underfunded and undermonitored fighter development program could he get a confirmation for his design.

The Flurry's development was littered with structural issues and deficits, mostly corresponding to the large size of the Squall payload in comparison to the ship, reducing size for armour or engines. The half-hearted solutions to these problems resulted in the Flurry having an abysmal top speed and thin armour/hull plating for a fighter of its calibre. Another difficulty was the inefficiency of the Squall missiles on the payload; their unique arming system often meant they were shot down as soon as they were fired, or would find(and miss) targets completely separate from the bomber's target. These inefficiencies, coupled with the admiral's insistence on using pure Squalls, lead to the project being denied and stonewalled from mass production.

A new team was eventually appointed to head the Flurry's development, which extensively modified the Squalls used in the Flurry to better serve its purpose. Ironically, they were changed so drastically from the base model that the original admiral who initiated the project quit it out of rage that his beloved Squalls were being tainted. Regardless, the end product was deemed decent enough to be officially put into the Diktat's roster; even if only to reduce its reliance on exported models of fighters.

Best described as a flying Dual Flak cannon, the Bretasinge provides heavy-duty point defense in all directions but suffers from sub-par armour and hull plating for its overblown size, as well as a lack of a shield generator. Only really finds optimal usage when its lack of defense can be supported by its mothership.

Due to lax regulations, undercut funding, and general apathy from Andrada, the Sindrian Diktat's few original fighter projects often mix zany ideas with incompatible hullmods, ending up with fighters that act more like proof of concepts than actually useful designs. The few that get the Lion's attention and manage to reach mass production in Diktat circles often don't perform quite as well as existing mass production fighters.

The Bretasinge was born of a noble, yet shortsighted idea; the idea to strap a dual flak turret to a large fighter to make it the ultimate point defense fighter. However, this idea soon fell flat when confronted with reality; the Bretasinge's development, like the Flurry's, was riddled with issues, mostly born out of constraints of space. Rather unfortunately, the reactor, engine and coolant systems among others required to maintain a medium flak turret requires a ship at least at frigate size, yet the leads refused to give in and powered through, fixing these glaring issues with ever more haphazardous bandaid solutions, such as removing armour plating to increase speed, removing unecessary components, replacing a human crew with a Delta-class AI core and more.

The resulting fighter was massive; barely managing to get into the corvette weight class and hence LPC rights. Despite this, much of its armour plating is slipshod and weak, with many integral parts even exposed to space, making it much weaker than its size might imply. The removal of "unecessary systems" led to the Bretasinge losing its shield generator, and the usage of cheap, inefficient components to compensate for underfunding led to its turret suffering from permanent deficits in its function. Its large size(and tendency to overheat in bays) has also made it a logistical nightmare to use. Its only real advantage is the sheer efficiency at which a dual flak turret shreds through any missile or fighter coming at it.

Ironically enough, the Bretasinge got its name from two tangents; One regarding how one of the leads was an enthusiast in old Earth cultures, and one regarding its tendency to singe anyone who touched it due to its lack of a proper cooling system.

Equipped with an omni-directional Vulcan, respectable durability and speed, the Bretais can provide competent area denial on nearby fighters and missiles, only held back by a logistical and communicational dependency on its mothership rendering its engagement range practically moot.

Due to lax regulations, undercut funding, and general apathy from Andrada, the Sindrian Diktat's few original fighter projects often mix zany ideas with incompatible hullmods, ending up with fighters that act more like proof of concepts than actually useful designs. The few that get the Lion's attention and manage to reach mass production in Diktat circles often don't perform quite as well as existing mass production fighters.

After the failure of the Bretasinge, the team that created it set out to right their wrongs by creating an actually viable fighter design. Against the protest of many higher ups and through much grueling effort fighting bureacratic bloat, they finally managed to get a second warrant to create another fighter; though under the threat of quite literally being beheaded by orders of the Lion if they failed again. With the stakes higher than ever before, they got to work quickly.

In a twist of fate, the Bretais' development went through surprisingly smoothly; downsizing the size of the Bretasinge chassis and its mount allowed for far more leeway for appropriate systems, meaning it could be outfitted to a far more reasonable standard. Usage of more efficient high-tech engines allowed for more space for shielding, armour and even specialized point defense systems to be installed on the chassis. Including a proper cooling system; that way it would no longer singe anyone who put their hands on it.

The result was a surprisingly efficient and logistically cheap support fighter, suitable for use as a mobile flying Vulcan turret while not sacrificing on every other aspect of its construction like the Bretasinge. To date, it is the most successful design to come from the Diktat's engineers, with it proudly being flown on many a carrier in Diktat fleets.

A hastily-retrofitted civilian design, the Nephrops is technically an interceptor, but often fails to live up to this expectation on anything more than weak missiles.

The few that get the Lion's attention and manage to reach mass production in Diktat circles often don't perform quite as well as existing mass production fighters.

The Nephrops was never meant for mass production in military fleets; rather, it was envisioned as a ceremonial mech used for parades and military showcases. With a design resembling the iconic Volturnian Lobster and dual fireworks launchers embedded into its claw-like arms, it would bring life to anniverseries and parties by lighting up the sky. However, the Grand Executor himself had bigger plans for this unassuming mech, deciding to push it into service as the Diktat's first and original mech design.

However, the Nephrops adapted poorly to its new role; the firework launchers, while modified to now use light flak rounds, could only handle that without practically blowing off the ship, while slotting in a shield generator where there never should have been one also diminished its already civilian-grade plating. While fashionable and stylish on paper, the Nephrops performs about as well in combat as you could expect a glorified parade float to be.

A common refit of the PD Laser, inserting a q-switched power supply permitting ablation of the target. However, this has made the weapon less flux-efficient, and each under-powered bolt does very little damage to all but the weakest targets.

Essentially a large metal spike atached to an engine, the Incisor MRM provides cheap kinetic fire support for ships that can't afford to fly in the frontlines. While the missiles are extremely fast and logistically cheap due to their small payload, their fragility means that even a small PD net can thwart them efficiently, while their underwhelming damage makes them less appealing than other kinetic options on the market. Best used in large amounts where their numbers can overwhelm the PD grids of enemy ships.

Originally created by the Diktat, these missiles were soon rolled out to the greater Sector in an attempt to garner funds for the Diktat through the sale of their blueprints. Providing a cheap if underwhelming option for kinetic support, these missiles never really reached the same popularity as the dreaded Sabot or the reliable Squall, though it often still finds a place on missile ships that do not have any better options for mid-range kinetic support.

Unfortunately, it's flamboyant nickname, no doubt chosen by the Lion of Sindria himself, turned off many prospective buyers, and even those who do actually use it refuse to use its real name, instead referring to it as the "Super Heavy Mauler"; a major source of consternation for the Lion and his entourage.

Paladin PD systems are hard to come by in the contemporary Sector; not only was it already an uncommon sight pre-Collapse, but its niche role of PD combined with the requirement of a large energy to mount it, as well as the corruption of most known Paladin blueprints meant it was rarer to see one in use outside the Tri-Tachyon Corporation than spotting a red Volturnian Lobster on Volturn. The solution to this by intrepid independent engineers was the Tactical Superlaser; essentially the core of a Paladin with 5 Tactical Lasers attached to it, this reborn Paladin now serves as a long-range support weapon favoured by captains of ships like the Sunder. While possessing advanced targeting systems from the Paladin allowing it to fire over allies, the horrific flux generation of the weapon ultimately meant it only became somewhat more popular than its predecessors.

This port is usually used to release fireworks from Lion's Guard ships during military parades, but can quickly be refitted into an inefficient flare launcher in times of combat. Often used in lieu of proper PD on Lion's Guard warships, despite their underwhelming performance in actually stopping missiles or fighters.

A Squall MRLS rack built into the Vanquisher. Fitted with an autoloader and missile fabricator, the Squall MRLS Tube can continually produce new munitions, but each missile launch now requires flux to compensate for this and each salvo is smaller as a result. Often used as a long-range shield suppression device.

A Locust SRM Launcher variant built into the Vanquisher(LG). Fitted with an autoloader and missile fabricator, the Termite SRM Tube can continually produce new munitions, but each missile launch now requires flux to compensate for this and each salvo is smaller as a result. Often used as supplement PD for the otherwise PD-less LG Vanquisher.

An Autopulse Cannon integrated into the front of the Impinge(LG). While the direct connection to ship-bound capacitors liberates the Integrated Autopulse Carbine from ammunition constraints that plague its modular relative, modifications needed to keep the weapon decently flux-efficient diffuse the destructive potency of each bolt. Often considered more a liability than a valuable asset by most commanders.

A colossal variant of the modular Graviton Beam, built into the Voyager's right flank. When activated, uses power directly siphoned from the Voyager's reactor to rip open holes in spacetime at a rate and intensity previously unheard of. The horrific amount of gravitons generated by this action can heavily stress all but the toughest shields, while their excited nature and sheer numerosity cause them to deal hard flux rather than the usual soft flux of the smaller Graviton Beam. The processes needed to keep the weapon from adversely affecting reactor performance produce a large amount of flux however.
The left claw of the Langusta has been outfitted with an inbuilt Light Autocannon, boasting a faster autoloading system allowing it to fire at a faster rate than its modular cousin.
The right claw of the Langusta has been outfitted with an inbuilt Heavy Mortar, boasting larger shells allowing it to do somewhat more damage than its modular cousin.

A spin-off of the Incisor MRM, which utilizes a larger, more durable warhead and more powerful engines at the cost of tracking. Can output ruinous damage, but the upgraded thrusters suffer from a horrifically short flight time, drastically reducing the range of the missiles. This same fact is why it was pulled from the ship-borne weapons market and now only exists on fighters like the Woodpecker.

A short-ranged mining lance usually used to carve chunks of ore off asteroids. While technically boasting more damage than the refitted Mining Laser, it also sports far shorter range which eclipses any true benefit this makeshift weapon may have over its rival.

An offshoot of the Paladin, the Targe Autolaser contains derivative technology from its larger brethren that allows it to primarily target fighters; its low-yield laser does little to ship-grade armour, but excels against mine-based projectiles. The weapon itself is slaved to a rotating gyro on the Legate, allowing it 360 degree coverage on a fixed rotation.
A downscaled, diffuse variant of the Heavy Blaster. While lacking much of the punch of its modular version, it's still capable of putting down heavy damage for its calibre.

The Laticlavus was originally meant as a PD destroyer, proposed as a viable solution to the sudden vacuum in PD caused by the mass restructuring of the Diktat's fighter doctrine; however, midway in development the Lion himself visited the facilities to view the upcoming ship designs. He was extremely disappointed and said quote, "Such unpatriotic ships that insult the abilities of our esteemed officials should be thrown into the trash. Besides, we already have the Monitor.", before firing(and presumably executing) half the development team and demanding that they start over from scratch. Under even more crunch time than ever, the remainder of the team was forced to completely revamp the design and role of the Laticlavus.

Nowadays, the Laticlavus acts as a fire support destroyer; while still possessing a built in point defense AI from its original role, it's proprietary Shield Polarity Inverser system allows it to temporarily degrade the effectiveness of enemy ship's shielding, allowing surrounding, more heavily-armed ships to punch harder at them. Despite this, its fragility would dissuade most from bringing it into active combat; a fact many Lion's Guard officers loathe.

Another defining trait is that most were made to be produced from parts of other ships; usually stored and decommissioned hulls from the Night of the Navy Partition in 198, where Andrada decommissioned half the Diktat Navy overnight in an attempt to accelerate the development of the Diktat's autarky solutions to imported hulls.

While it does have two synergy mounts, its paper-thin armour and lack of protective hull plating make it extremely vulnerable when it can't utilize its horrific speed against its enemies.

In the end, while not squaring up to its rival the Dominator, the Vanquisher can still hold the battleline admirably well, using a combination of its inbuilt Squall missile tubes and Capacitor Augment to whittle down enemy lineships.

(Being a civilian ship there are, of course, no facilities for fighter repair and rearmament).

The Starliner is equipped with a forward shield to ensure passenger safety and protect the hull from routine abrasion. Refitted for the current realities of the Sector, this ship class is routinely equipped with all-band anti-missile flare launchers as well as a number of gun turrets; this serves not only to evoke a sense of adventure, but discourage casual piracy while justifying a "munitions surcharge" on each ticket sale.

Modified for service in the blazing fires of inner Askonia, it boasts both a built-in modified Autopulse Cannon that is capable of firing in great bursts of power, as well as an experimental Conduit Shroud system of enigmatic nature, allowing it to focus its flux into a protective barrier around it that selectively dampens and amplifies certain types of damage; although its delicate components tend to fail in prolonged engagements, reducing the effectiveness of flux drain per use. Commanding the battlefield as the Supreme Executor's hammer, the Impinge shall cleave down any foes foolish enough to challenge the Sindrian Diktat; or so the holoposters claim.

A common rumor among spacefarers is that the Impinge is no original design, but a derivative of an ancient Domain-era capital; one now lost to time and the technological rot of the Sector. Indeed, some historical texts do describe a capital-class design suspiciously similar to the Impinge; but the Ministry of Information is always quick to shut these down as baseless slander, attacks by Degenerates or a mix of both.

However, the Jackdaw's ultimate claim to fame is the odd arrangement of its generators; while most ships spread their generators out among the length of the ship, the Jackdaw's are arranged along the centre of the ship; allowing these generators to collectively supply targeting systems associated with the prominent medium mount a generous allotment of energy to better their calculations, increasing medium weapon range, while sacrificing the range of small weapons in the process. This in practice means that the Jackdaw must rely solely on its medium mount for offensive purposes, utilising its mobility to give this mount ample space to strike.

The most interesting feature on this dull ship however, is its main mount; situated on a perpetually rotating gyro, the Targe Autolaser mounted on it can sweep the battlefield for any fighters, missiles or especially mines that are in its range. Possessing calibrations that allow it to damage mines to a higher extent than other objects, it has gained the unofficial name "Minesweeper" by Diktat crews for its uncanny ability to ward off the otherwise deadly barrage of such things from ships and stations alike.

Ships made by the Sindrian Diktat are often hampered in productive quality by presence of tight constraints all across the board, as well as the meddling of the Supreme Executor Andrada in their development who often demands the addition or modification of systems plain illogical to the function or design of the ship. Another defining trait is that most were made to be produced from parts of other ships; usually stored and decommissioned hulls from the Night of the Navy Partition in 198, where Andrada decommissioned half the Diktat Navy overnight in an attempt to accelerate the development of the Diktat's autarky solutions to imported hulls.

A technologically advanced cruiser seemingly based on the Vanquisher, the Sagittarii boasts a complex array of vector-based targeting systems, allowing its formidable array of medium slots to unleash brutal suppressive fire from similarly oppressive ranges. If found in the range of knife-fighting combatants, the Sagittarii can rapidly switch power from targeting systems to an array of ammo feeders and energy banks, enabling it to unleash truly monstrous amounts of firepower at close range, enough to deter any would-be attackers. Despite these advantages, its rear is relatively undefended, relying on escorts to keep flankers from reaching its blind spot.

Modified for operations in the Askonia system under orders from Supreme Executor Philip Andrada, this hull includes integrated solar shielding as well as a peculiar internal cladding provided by an industrial conglomerate out of Sindria itself. That the chief designer, appointed by the Supreme Executor for his many cycles of loyal service, sits on the board of that conglomerate is simply an example of the unity and efficiency of the Sindrian Polity. Other than the base changes, this refitted variant of the Regulus has swapped out its rear mounts and some of its engine burners for a complex array of instruments, that seem to scan for the presence of Special Modifications and project buffs to fellow Lion's Guard ships bearing them. While dangerous in the context of other Lion's Guard ships, the Regulus(LG) is also slower and weaker than its baseline cousin, and usually ends up painting a massive target on itself in battles.

Oddly large and bulky for a frigate, the Regulus is intended to be a leader for frigate formations, increasing the effectiveness of wolfpack-based fleets. Boasting a modified Drive Field Stabiliser that can improve the speed and acceleration of surrounding ships, as well as a robust PD-friendly weapons layout, its presence can greatly benefit the frigates it is intended to be around. However, its lackluster mobility can leave it struggling to keep up with its intended escorts; and due to this, the Regulus may often find a new role in cruiser or capital-heavy fleets, serving as a PD platform for slower ships, as well as improving their speed, despite the diminishing effects of the drive stabilisation effect on larger ships.

Itsdefinitely a ship, thats for sure. Its got a functional bridge, engines, weapons, shields, yknow, the stuff that youd expect a ship to be. The make and design is unfamiliar to me, but thats a given since this thing was literally hanging out in a top-secret weapons testing platform or something, heh.

But theres one thing that really confounds me about this ship. Theres a massive hollow space within the structure of the ship that extends across its area. There are plenty of machines and scaffolding stuffed inside it, but the way that its crudely connected into ripped out ports makes it look like it was never supposed to hold those parts they way theyre wedged in, like it was made for something else. Plus, the bridge seems incredibly ungainly and crudely attached to the rest of the ship; we had to do some emergency reinforcement on its connection to the main hull to keep it from falling off before we dragged it out the yard into space. Its really strange for whats supposed to be a spaceship - the bridge is the brain of the ship as they say, it should be counterintuitive to make the bridge that weakly attached.

If you ask meit reminds me of a shell. The way the walls of that hollow are made to be smooth, seemingly accommodating to flesh; some of the salvors reported that it felt amazing to touch, which is really weird for a place filled with unfeeling mechanical wires and trusses. Plus, some of the ports we found, really remind me of the way some cybernetics would stab wires into open ports of the arms or necks of their users, not coolant tubes or electrical wiring.

But what could potentially fit into that shell? No idea, Im an engineering officer chief, not a biologist.

what are you doing here?
Inverts the polarity of the target's shields, causing them to take double their flux per damage for 10 seconds.
Uses flux from capacitors to boost weapon damage by 25% for 5 seconds.
Uses flux from capacitors to increase drive power, energy weapon rate of fire and maneuveribility.

Activates accelerated effects of Temporal Shell for 10 seconds and supercharges weapon banks, resulting in greatly increase ammo regeneration for ammo-using weapons. However, the resulting temporal stresses tear the ship apart afterwards.
Creates a barrier that reduces kinetic and HE damage but increases energy and fragmentation damage. Consumes 25% flux which decays by 5% after every use, capping at 5%.

Activates a combat-rated variant of the Drive Field Stabiliser that improves the performance of allied ship's drives in a range of around 600su, increasing their max speed and acceleration. Effects are diminished on capital ships and cruisers.

Draws energy away from targeting systems to activate a series of rapid ammo feeders and energy banks, increasing the firerate of ballistics weapons and the damage of energy weapons at the cost of drastically reducing weapons range while active.

The Sindrian Diktat is a polity founded in a relatively recent Hegemony military intervention in the Askonia system led by Admiral Philip Andrada, formerly of the Hegemony Navy. Andrada's Hegemony psych profile describes him as "intelligent, charismatic, yet prone to narcissistic excess". In his words, the Diktat was "formed in the crucible of the Askonia Crisis and with it a new people: a race of humans with emboldened spirit and clarity of purpose; stronger, possessing the will and determination to overcome the divisions and petty parliamentary politics that bred only chaos when tested by the collapse of the Gate System." Considered by the Sector at large to be a military dictatorship.

Despite this, the Sindrian Diktat has managed to survive a tumultous two decades in power, cleverly taking advantage of political events to further its territorial claims, exploiting loopholes and gray areas in political statements, manipulating other factions and prying into the uses of Domain-Era tech like no other faction. Currently, the Diktat stands as a semi-legitimate power in the Sector, not because other factions respect it, but because a war to remove it from power would be far too bloody to justify the returns. Despite this, the situation of the Diktat steadily grows more and more tumultous by the Cycles; one begs to wonder just how long the Diktat can continue to hold its favourable position in the Sector's political landscape.
